title: The 25 Best Online MPH Programs of 2021 | PublicHealth.org
author: PublicHealth org Staff
description: If you're considering a master's in public health, you can find a list of the best online MPH programs with this resource.
cleaned_text: A master of public health (MPH) offers a versatile education tailored to a unique career path, with courses covering the intersection of disease, social and behavioral science, biostatistics, community education, and health policy. The degree typically takes about two years to complete, though programs might offer accelerated formats for professionals already in the field. Students completing their coursework part-time might need longer to graduate. Earning an MPH degree can help professionals land a variety of roles within the public health field. Many graduates become epidemiologists, conducting work as experts in the spread of diseases. In addition to interesting work, the epidemiology career path offers lucrative compensation and promising career growth. Epidemiologists earn a [median annual salary of $70,990](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/life-physical-and-social-science/epidemiologists.htm), according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). The BLS also projects the number of jobs for epidemiologists to increase by 5% between 2019 and 2029. MPH students who specialize in education often become community health educators. The BLS reports that these professionals make [median earnings of nearly $47,000](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/community-and-social-service/health-educators.htm), and the projected job growth from 2019 to 2029 could reach 13%, much faster than the national average for all occupations. Students juggling multiple responsibilities, including jobs and family obligations, may prefer to pursue a master's in public health online. Online MPH programs, which often feature an asynchronous class delivery format, give degree-seekers the flexibility to study at their own convenience. Plus, by cutting out the commute to campus, distance learners can save significant time and money. Featured Online Programs To help you select the right online MPH program for you, we've used our ranking methodology to select the top online MPH programs. [Read about our ranking methodology here.](/methodology/) Top 10 Online MPH Programs - [University of Florida](#rank1)- Gainesville, FL - [University of California-Berkeley](#rank2)- Berkeley, CA - [New York University](#rank3)- New York, NY - [Samford University](#rank4)- Birmingham, - [Oklahoma State University-Main Campus](#rank5)- [The - [West Morgantown, Alabama](#rank8)- Tuscaloosa, AL - [University Southern California](#rank9)- Los Angeles, CA - [Ohio University-Main Campus](#rank10)- Athens, OH Best Online MPH Programs for 2021 University of Florida The [master's in public health](https://mph.ufl.edu/) at UF offers a 48-credit curriculum for individuals who want to work in research or within the community health field. Students can choose to pursue their degree at UF's Gainesville campus or through online learning. Distance learners do not need to fulfill any on-campus requirements. They watch prerecorded lectures on their own time and take proctored exams online. Core courses cover statistical methods, epidemiology, and the U.S. healthcare system. The curriculum also requires a public health internship for 3-6 credits and an integrated learning experience or capstone project. Online degree-seekers can choose from two concentrations: public health practice and behavioral health sciences. In addition, students can choose to enroll in a 42-credit MPH program for health professionals who already hold a terminal degree within their field. Applicants may apply with a bachelor's degree and a minimum 3.0 undergraduate GPA. Although UF normally requires GRE scores, the school is currently waiving that requirement because of the COVID-19 pandemic. This online MPH holds accreditation from the Council on Education for Public Health. UF is regionally accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges. [Visit School Site](https://mph.ufl.edu) University of California - Berkeley UC Berkeley offers a mostly online, part-time [master of public health](https://publichealth.berkeley.edu/academics/online/online-mph/) that prioritizes healthcare management, health policy and economics, and community health sciences. The curriculum also relies heavily on qualitative and quantitative research courses. The program comprises 90% online and 10% on-campus coursework. Distance learning classes follow an asynchronous learning format, and students can expect to spend 15-17 hours on coursework each week. Degree-seekers must complete a 130-hour practicum that allows them to gain real work experience in the field. The full program lasts 2.5 years, and students must pass a comprehensive exam before graduating. Students may pursue the general public health track or choose between concentrations in health policy and management or epidemiology and biostatistics. Qualified applicants possess a bachelor's degree and have passed at least one college-level statistics course with a "B+" or better. The university holds accreditation from the Western Association of Schools and Colleges. The public health department is also accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health. [Visit School Site](https://publichealth.berkeley.edu/academics/online/online-mph) New York University While NYU offers a general master of public health with several concentrations on campus, the school recently created an [online MPH](https://publichealth.nyu.edu/master-public-health/concentrations/sustainable-development-goals) focused on sustainable development goals. The degree focuses on training students for jobs meant to help global communities reach the health-related sustainable development goals from the United Nations. Graduates often go on to work for government or nonprofit organizations that develop equitable solutions for public health challenges. Distance learners can follow a two-year full-time or 2.5-year part-time format. Students take 33 credits of required courses like global health informatics and epidemiology along with three electives. Elective courses include HIV/AIDS from a global perspective and perspectives on migrant health and human rights. Additionally, degree-seekers must complete 180 hours of an applied practice experience and a two-credit integrated learning experience. Interested individuals can apply by submitting their undergraduate transcripts, a personal statement, and two professional recommendation letters. Although NYU does not specify a minimum GPA for admission, the program is competitive. The school recommends applicants possess at least three years of work experience in a national or subnational health system. NYU holds regional accreditation from the Middle States Commission on Higher Education. The MPH is accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health. [Visit School Site](https://publichealth.nyu.edu/master-public-health/concentrations/sustainable-development-goals) Samford University Located in Birmingham, Alabama, Samford University offers an [online master of public health](https://www.samford.edu/publichealth/master-of-public-health) that lasts about two years. The program takes a multidisciplinary approach, teaching students about global health problems and equipping them with the research skills and scientific knowledge to tackle those problems. Courses include epidemiology, public health programs in developing countries, biostatistics, and global health systems. During their last semester, degree-seekers finish off the 42-credit curriculum with an integrative learning experience. The MPH program at Samford does not offer concentrations but covers a broad range of topics. Graduates study topics like the prevention of infectious diseases, the impact of health policies, and environmental contaminants. Applicants should submit their undergraduate transcripts showing at least a 3.0 GPA and standardized test scores from the GRE or MAT. They should also submit three reference letters. Samford holds accreditation from the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges. [Visit School Site](https://www.samford.edu/publichealth/master-of-public-health) Oklahoma State University - Main Campus MPH students at OSU can pursue the university's [public health graduate program](https://osuonline.okstate.edu/programs/graduate/public-health-master-of-science.html) entirely through online learning. The curriculum considers health problems at the local, national, and international levels. Degree-seekers also learn about improving health services for rural and underserved populations. The 42-credit degree includes courses covering epidemiology, statistical methods, strategic health communications, and cultural issues in health. Courses last eight or 16 weeks and follow an asynchronous format, meaning that students can complete assignments on their own time. This MPH program does not offer concentrations but instead takes an interdisciplinary view. To apply, prospective students can submit their undergraduate transcripts and a statement of purpose outlining their interest in the program and professional goals. OSU is accredited by the Higher Learning Commission. The MPH holds accreditation from the Council on Education for Public Health. [Visit School Site](https://osuonline.okstate.edu/programs/graduate/public-health-master-of-science.html) The University of West Florida At Pensacola-based UWF, the [master's in public health](https://onlinedegrees.uwf.edu/online-degrees/mph-masters-public-health/) requires 42 credits of coursework and lasts 24-30 months. The program prepares graduates for careers as epidemiologists, health educators, community health workers, and emergency management directors. The online degree includes asynchronous foundational, concentration, and practicum courses. Students can pursue a generalist MPH or choose a specialty in global health or health promotion, education, and behavior. The practicum involves a two-part, six-credit internship on location with an approved preceptor. Distance learners can work with faculty members and participate in on-campus research and present the outcomes of their research at national conferences. Incoming students may transfer up to nine course credits. The MPH program is accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health. The university is accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges. [Visit School Site](https://onlinedegrees.uwf.edu/online-degrees/mph-masters-public-health) West Virginia University Morgantown's public, land-grant university runs several graduate and undergraduate programs, including a [master's in public health online](https://publichealth.wvu.edu/students/graduate-programs/master-of-public-health/). Graduates of the program have gone on to work at health departments, clinics, research institutions, and federal agencies. An applied practice experience at a health-related agency includes 180 contact hours on location. Degree-seekers can fulfill this requirement at university research departments or local community health centers. The curriculum includes several concentration options, such as those below: - Biostatistics - Epidemiology - Health Policy - Occupational and Environmental Health Sciences - Social and Behavioral Sciences To apply, individuals must possess a bachelor's degree with a minimum 3.0 GPA. Although they do not necessarily need a degree in public health, they should be competent in math. WVU holds accreditation from the Higher Learning Commission, and the public health master's is accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health. [Visit School Site](https://publichealth.wvu.edu/students/graduate-programs/master-of-public-health) The University of Alabama A public research university in Tuscaloosa, UA facilitates several online programs for graduate and nontraditional students through its College of Continuing Studies, including the online [MPH program](https://bamabydistance.ua.edu/degrees/master-of-public-health/) comprising 42 credits. The program follows a flexible format so that working professionals may enroll. Students take 33 credits of required courses and six elective credits, which include courses like worksite health promotion, sexuality education, and women and health. They must also fulfill a three-hour applied practical experience requirement. Graduates may sit for the Certified Health Education Specialist, Master Certified Health Education Specialist, and Certified Public Health professional certification exams. Prospective students may apply by submitting an undergraduate transcript with a minimum 3.0 GPA; those with a lower GPA must send in GRE scores. Applicants should also send in three recommendation letters. UA is regionally accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges. The public health program holds accreditation from the Council on Education for Public Health. [Visit School Site](https://bamabydistance.ua.edu/degrees/master-of-public-health) University of Southern California The Keck School of Medicine at USC offers an [MPH degree](https://mphdegree.usc.edu/) with a fast-track option that allows students to graduate within one year. [Visit School Site](https://und.edu/programs/public-health-mph/index.html) University of Massachusetts - Amherst UM Amherst offers a 42-credit [master's in public health](https://www.umass.edu/sphhs/community-health-education/masters-programs/master-public-health-mph) especially for experienced healthcare workers who want to solve problems within the public health system. [Visit School Site](https://www.madonna.edu/academics/programs/public-health-mph) Applying to an Online MPH Program Each school selects their own admission requirements for public health master's programs. Generally speaking, prospective students should hold a bachelor's degree. They must typically apply by submitting their undergraduate transcripts and letters of recommendation. Schools do not always require applicants to hold their degree in public health or a related field, but they usually set minimum GPA requirements ranging from 2.5-3.2. Many, but not all, schools require applicants to send in GRE or GMAT scores. Some programs require 1-2 years of work experience within the public health or healthcare field. Schools may also impose requirements based on an applicant's chosen specialization. Biostatistics students, for example, may need to show a passing grade in calculus on their undergraduate transcript to demonstrate their readiness for the graduate-level coursework. Explore [The Best Bachelor's Degrees in Public Health.](/rankings/bachelors/) Frequently Asked Questions What public health specializations are available for master's degrees? MPH students can often choose a concentration to specialize their expertise in a certain area. Common specializations include epidemiology, biostatistics, health services administration, disaster management and emergency preparedness, environmental health science, health policy, global health, and community health education. What is accreditation, and why is it important? Through the accreditation system, colleges and academic programs receive evaluations intended to ensure the quality of their degrees. Accredited programs demonstrate that students have received a valuable education, giving students and their employers confidence in their degrees. Public health students should look for programs accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health (CEPH). Is a master's in public health a good degree? A well-respected degree within the field of public health, an MPH gives access to interesting, well-paid career options. For those considering a career in the public health field, whether through research, education, or advocacy, an MPH is a great choice. What can I do with a MPH degree? MPH graduates go into many different fields. Public health professionals might become epidemiologists and researchers, studying how diseases and other ailments spread through societies. Others might devote their careers to public health education, or they could become faculty members at colleges. MPH holders might prefer to shape policies and laws relating to public health, becoming policy advisors or congressional staffers.
